basics.name: Adrian Alan Pol
basics.label: Software Engineer
basics.summary: I am a software engineer and machine learning researcher working with 4000 scientists on the CMS experiment at the CERN Large Hadron Collider. I work with multi-disciplinary teams to integrate state-of-the-art deep learning in the production code for the operation of our experiment. My current projects include computer vision, anomaly detection and efficient model inference in sub-100ns latency.
basics.introduction1: Since 2013, I have worked at CERN, the largest particle physics laboratory in the world, and at Princeton University as Postdoctoral Research Associate. During this time, I have worked on the CMS experiment, which operates at the Large Hadron Collider, arguably the most technically advanced machine humans have ever built. My everyday work and research focuses on machine learning applications to the trigger system which filters the incoming data stream from the collisions.
basics.introduction2: I earned my PhD in Computer Science from the University of Paris Saclay. Before that, I studied Telecommunications Engineering at the Technical University of Denmark and the National University of Singapore; and Electrical Engineering at the Lodz University of Technology and the Polytechnic University of Turin.
basics.introduction3: I enjoy good tea and wine.

news.title: Talk at Rutgers HEX Seminar at Rutgers University, New Jersey, United States
news.content: Title: Model Compression for the Hardware Trigger. Abstract: The CERN Large Hadron Collider (LHC) particle accelerator operates at a nominal collision rate of 40 MHz. The experiments around the accelerator ring must reduce the volume of recorded data due to storage constraints and technological limitations.  Trigger systems are used to filter the incoming data stream in real-time. The Compact Muon Solenoid (CMS) experiment deploys a two-stage trigger system. The first stage is implemented in hardware (ASICs and FPGAs) and reduces the 40 MHz input to a 100 kHz event rate in sub 10 us latency. With the planned LHC high-luminosity upgrade, Phase 2, the number of simultaneous collisions per event will surge approximately four-fold, and the complexity of the selection algorithms will increase. The high energy physics (HEP) community is investigating the feasibility of deploying more deep-learning-based solutions to meet these demands. However, we cannot run over-parametrized neural networks with float64 precision on hardware due to resource limitations. In this talk, I overview available tools and methods for model compression, i.e. quantization, pruning and knowledge distillation. These methods are used beyond HEP, e.g. for autonomous vehicles or mobile devices. They will allow us to meet the hardware trigger's unprecedented latency and resource constraints.

news.title: Our paper was accepted for publication in Machine Learning: Science and Technology journal
news.content: Title: Lightweight jet reconstruction and identification as an object detection task. Abstract: We apply object detection techniques based on deep convolutional blocks to end-to-end jet identification and reconstruction tasks encountered at the CERN large hadron collider (LHC). Collision events produced at the LHC and represented as an image composed of calorimeter and tracker cells are given as an input to a Single Shot Detection network. The algorithm, named PFJet-SSD performs simultaneous localization, classification and regression tasks to cluster jets and reconstruct their features. This all-in-one single feed-forward pass gives advantages in terms of execution time and an improved accuracy w.r.t. traditional rule-based methods. A further gain is obtained from network slimming, homogeneous quantization, and optimized runtime for meeting memory and latency constraints of a typical real-time processing environment. We experiment with 8-bit and ternary quantization, benchmarking their accuracy and inference latency against a single-precision floating-point. We show that the ternary network closely matches the performance of its full-precision equivalent and outperforms the state-of-the-art rule-based algorithm. Finally, we report the inference latency on different hardware platforms and discuss future applications.

news.title: Contribution at the 5th Inter-experiment Machine Learning Workshop at CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
news.content: Title: ML for SUEP Detection. Abstract: We explore a possible avenue for detecting Dark Showers that manifest as Soft Unclustered Energy Patterns (SUEP) in the detector with the use of supervised machine learning techniques and transfer learning. We employ a ResNet model based on Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) to classify events. Additionally, a robust, data-driven background estimation technique is embedded into the model architecture through a Distance Correlation (DiSco) term in the loss function of the network; this achieves decorrelation between the classifier output and another physics-motivated discriminant in order to estimate background in the signal region through the ABCD method.

news.title: Co-organizer of Fundamentals of Deep Learning workshop at AMLD 2022 at EPFL, Lausanne, Switzerland
news.content: In this workshop, students learned how deep learning works through hands-on exercises in popular artificial intelligence areas namely Computer Vision (CV) and Natural Language Processing (NLP). They trained deep learning models from scratch, learn tools and tricks to achieve highly accurate results by working on binary, multi-class, and text generation scenarios. They also learned to leverage freely available, state-of-the-art pre-trained models to save time and get your deep learning application up and running quickly through Transfer Learning. Other core concepts of learning include Data Augmentation, Feature Extraction, Fine Tuning, Embeddings, and loss functions.

news.title: Our book 'Artificial Intelligence for High Energy Physics' was published by World Scientific Publishing Company
news.content: From the book description on Amazon. The Higgs boson discovery at the Large Hadron Collider in 2012 relied on boosted decision trees. Since then, high energy physics (HEP) has applied modern machine learning (ML) techniques to all stages of the data analysis pipeline, from raw data processing to statistical analysis. The unique requirements of HEP data analysis, the availability of high-quality simulators, the complexity of the data structures (which rarely are image-like), the control of uncertainties expected from scientific measurements, and the exabyte-scale datasets require the development of HEP-specific ML techniques. While these developments proceed at full speed along many paths, the nineteen reviews in this book offer a self-contained, pedagogical introduction to ML models' real-life applications in HEP, written by some of the foremost experts in their area.
